1.headline: Where Is Breast Cancer?
1.text: Breast cancer is the worldâ€™s most common cancer in women, with an estimated 1.4 million new cases diagnosed every year.

2.headline: Where Does Breast Cancer Kill?
2.text: While women in highly developed countries have higher diagnosis rates of breast cancer, women in the developing world who have breast cancer are more likely to die from the disease.
2.subtext: For each country, deaths per 100 cases were calculated by dividing mortality rate by incidence rate.

3.headline: High Mortality in Africa
3.text: Many of the poorest countries are in Africa, where a high percentage of breast cancer cases result in death. Poverty and misinformation keep women from seeking medical help. Even those who receive a diagnosis earlier can face delays in treatment because of scarce resources and dysfunctional health systems.
3.subtext: Incomplete reporting can make rates of breast cancer in developing countries look lower than they are.

4.headline: Divide Among Mid-Level Nations
4.text: Among women in moderately developed countries, incidence is relatively low but mortality is high. An exception is China, where incidence and mortality have been lower.

5.headline: Wealthier Nations
5.text: Among more highly developed nations, Arab countries tend to have lower incidence but higher mortality. By comparison, the ratio of deaths to new cases is lower in Latin America.

6.headline: The Richest Countries
6.text: Incidence is high but mortality is low in the United States and many Western and Northern European countries, in part because of a history of widespread screening and access to treatment.
